content: The Act is titled the "King Holiday and Service Act of 1994" and establishes the Martin Luther King, Jr. Federal Holiday Commission. The Act titled "King Holiday and Service Act of 1994" amends various sections including adding the Chief Executive Officer of the Corporation for National and Community Service to the Commission. The Act authorizes appropriations for the Martin Luther King Holiday Commission, with increasing amounts allocated for fiscal years 1995 to 1999. Additionally, it sets limits on the duration of details for federal employees to the Commission. The Martin Luther King Holiday Commission is authorized appropriations with increasing amounts allocated for fiscal years 1995 to 1999, including $450,000 for fiscal year 1998 and $500,000 for fiscal year 1999. Section 8 is also amended accordingly. The Martin Luther King Holiday Commission is authorized appropriations with increasing amounts allocated for fiscal years 1995 to 1999, including $450,000 for fiscal year 1998 and $500,000 for fiscal year 1999. Section 8 is also amended accordingly. The Martin Luther King Holiday Commission is required to submit an annual report to the President and Congress detailing its activities, spending practices, and grants made in consultation with the Corporation for National and Community Service. The deadline for the report submission was changed from April 20, 1994, to September 30, 1999. The Martin Luther King Holiday Commission's annual report deadline was changed from April 20, 1994, to September 30, 1999. Additionally, funds appropriated to the Commission cannot be used for first class air travel or hotel accommodations. The Commission must adhere to specific accounting procedures defined by the Comptroller General and establish a reviewable accounting system. The Comptroller General has the authority to audit the Commission and access all necessary records for audits. The Corporation may provide grants for service opportunities on Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, focusing on activities reflecting his teachings such as cooperation among racial groups and social justice. Eligible entities can receive funding for these initiatives. Entities eligible for assistance under national services laws can receive grants for service opportunities on Martin Luther King, Jr. Day. The Corporation must consult with the Martin Luther King, Jr. Federal Holiday Commission when making grants. The Federal share of grants for service opportunities cannot exceed 30% of the total cost. Entities receiving grants for service opportunities must provide in-kind contributions towards the costs. Amendments are made to references in the National and Community Service Trust Act of 1993. Amendments are made to the National and Community Service Act of 1990, including changes to descriptions of national service participants, educational award eligibility requirements, and the civilian community corps. Amendments to the National and Community Service Act of 1990 include changing "Corps" to "Camps" and updating references to specific sections within the Act. Amendments to the Domestic Volunteer Service Act of 1973 involve changes in subparagraph indentation, correcting the execution of an amendment, and specifying effective dates for the amendments.
